The applicant brought proceedings under section CARDINAL of LAW ( GPE ) before the St ORG , requesting a declaratory decision that he was entitled to claim ORG CARDINAL from the company 's assets . He estimated the amount in dispute ( PERSON ) , which serves as the basis for calculating court fees , lawyers ' fees and other procedural costs , at LAW . Apparently this amount was what he expected to obtain as his quota in the insolvency proceedings . On the basis of this estimated amount in dispute , the applicant paid court fees of LAW .

CARDINAL . By decision of DATE the PERSON Regional Court , of its own motion , fixed the amount in dispute at ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL,CARDINAL.CARDINAL , holding that the claim was of a pecuniary nature and could not therefore be the subject of an estimate .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed claiming , inter alia , that the fixing of the amount in dispute violated his right of access to a court . He argued that since the liquidator had contested his claim , he had no choice other than to request a declaratory decision under section CARDINAL of LAW in order to participate in the insolvency proceedings , in which he could at best hope to obtain a small percentage of the overall amount claimed . It was excessive to take the overall amount claimed as the amount in dispute , because the ensuing court fees would exceed the amount he could realistically expect to obtain . The contested decision therefore prevented him in practice from pursuing his claims .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) dismissed the applicant 's appeal . It referred to its own established case - law and to ORG case - law which confirmed the view that in proceedings under section CARDINAL of LAW the amount the claimant wished to assert in the insolvency proceedings had to be taken as the amount in dispute , without regard to the quota likely to be obtained .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the extraordinary appeal on points of law lodged by the applicant , without examining the merits .

It referred to its established case - law according to which , in proceedings concerning a pecuniary claim , the amount of the claim was to be taken as the amount in dispute . CARDINAL . A creditor who wishes to participate in the proceedings must register his claims , indicating the facts and evidence on which they are based and their ranking ( section CARDINAL ) . A claim is deemed to be established if the trustee in bankruptcy or liquidator has acknowledged it and no other creditor has contested it .
CARDINAL . If a claim is contested , the creditor has to bring an action under section CARDINAL of LAW which , in so far as material , reads as follows :
“ Creditors whose claims continue to be contested as to their accuracy and ranking may seek have them established ... by means of a complaint directed against all the contesting parties . ”

CARDINAL . According to ORG case - law ( see , as a leading case , QUANTITY g , judgment of DATE ) , the amount in dispute for the purposes of an action under section CARDINAL of LAW is the amount of the claim which the creditor seeks to have admitted in the insolvency proceedings . In the above - mentioned case , ORG dealt with the claimant 's argument that it would be more appropriate to make an estimate of the amount in dispute . The court noted that as a general rule there was no scope for making an estimate of the amount in dispute where the subject of the action for a declaratory decision was a pecuniary claim . The question of whether a claim was recoverable or not was not material for fixing the amount in dispute , and in that respect there was no difference between proceedings under section CARDINAL of LAW and other civil proceedings . Moreover , an action under section CARDINAL also had effects outside the insolvency proceedings .
CARDINAL . Regarding the costs of proceedings concerning the admission of claims , section CARDINAL of LAW provides as follows :

“ The procedural costs are to be met from the estate in so far as the trustee in bankruptcy or liquidator has participated in the contesting of claims . The court may , however , require the ORG or liquidator to repay the procedural costs to the estate if he or she has contested claims or conducted the proceedings in a vexatious manner . ”
CARDINAL . Legal aid can be obtained under LAW ( Zivilprozeßordnung ) which , in so far as relevant , provides as follows :

“ Natural persons who are a party to proceedings shall be granted full or partial legal aid to the extent that they are unable to pay the cost of participating in the proceedings without adverse effects on their capacity to meet necessary expenditure , and the intended action or defence is not manifestly vexatious or without prospects of success . Necessary expenditure shall be taken to mean the expenditure required to provide the person concerned and his or her dependants with a basic standard of living . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure enumerates the costs which can be covered by legal aid :
“ Legal aid in respect of a specific set of proceedings may cover ... the following :
( CARDINAL ) NORP exemption from :
( a ) NORP court fees ... ”
CARDINAL . Regarding the collection of court fees , section CARDINAL of LAW ( Gerichtliches Einbringungsgesetz ) , in so far as material , provides :
“ ( CARDINAL ) A request for extension of the time - limit for payment , or for payment in instalments , may be granted if collection would cause particular hardship to the person concerned ...
( CARDINAL ) A request for fees and costs to be reduced may be granted if their collection would cause particular hardship to the person concerned ... ”
